newsitem.title: USA: Documents suggest tobacco firms courted youths.
newsitem.headline: Documents suggest tobacco firms courted youths.

text.p: The tobacco industry manipulated nicotine levels and courted underage smokers despite knowing for years that its product was toxic, according to tobacco industry documents cited Tuesday in a published report.

The Arizona Republic, citing confidential internal documents it had obtained, said the Liggett Group Inc. weighed using a synthetic substance in its products because of the "severe toxicity of nicotine."
The newspaper also said the tobacco industry tailored its marketing campaigns to specific groups, based on race, age and gender.
One memo states a new packaging should be used "so as to have more appeal to youth."
Another said 16- to 21-year-olds are "in the formative years (when) smoking starts and brand preferences are developed."

The documents were made public as part of a historic settlement between Liggett, Arizona and 21 other states that are suing major tobacco companies in an effort to recover the Medicaid costs of treating smoking-releated ailments.
The Republic said the documents, made available by the state attorney general's office at the paper's request, account for just a fraction of what exists. Most are under seal in various state courts.
But the newspaper said the information, made available Monday, offered an outline that suggests Liggett knew cigarettes were habit-forming.
It also pointed to evidence that the company grappled with the product's ill effects on health.

"Is it morally permissable to develop a safe method for administering a habit-forming drug, when, in doing so, the number of addicts will increase?" a company researcher asked in a 1978 memo from obtained by The Republic.
The document goes on to suggest that tobacco will always be used and that the company's real duty "lies in diminishing the adverse consequences."

A draft memo from 1970 also questions whether the Council for Tobacco Research should pursue studies of health-related problems linked to cigarettes, saying the efforts had failed to take pressure off the industry.
Additionally, the documents show that Liggett watched its competitors closely, monitoring their efforts to win over potential customers.
According to a report prepared by the consulting firm Arthur D. Little, the tobacco industry tried to tailor its marketing to specific groups.
The newspaper said one section of the report said "Spanish and Negro groups like to purchase only the best of everything -- they are not looking for bargains."

The newspaper quoted another section of the report as saying "there must be a racial slant in the marketing efforts" directed toward minorities, "while in the case of the Jewish market, this is not a requirement."
Liggett Group is a unit of Brooke Group Ltd.
